title: EPA tightens limits on smog emissions
text:
EPA tightens limits on smog emissions Maureen Groppe , Star Washington Bureau 5:58 p.m. EDT October 1, 2015 Fourteen Indiana counties have ozone levels higher than new rules allow, but the agency says pollution is declining. Oppressive heat and high humidity settled in over the Washington skyline as record-breaking temperatures and ozone-laden haze prompted air-quality alerts in July 2010. (Photo: J. Scott Applewhite / AP 2010 file photo) 4 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
WASHINGTON – Pollution levels in 14 Indiana counties — including Marion — are higher than new ozone limits the federal government announced Thursday to reduce urban smog. 
But the Environmental Protection Agency says most areas will have until 2025 to meet the tougher limits, and smog-causing emissions are on the decline. 
Because of future reductions expected from tougher emissions rules on automobiles and power plants, the EPA projects that ozone levels in all Indiana counties will be below the new limit by 2025 without additional steps. 
EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy (Photo: Evan Vucci / AP 2015 file photo) 
"So we are not changing the world today, but we are telling the public about what we believe to be the healthy air that we're driving," said EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy. 
The National Association of Manufacturers, however, called the tightened limits overly burdensome, costly and misguided. 
Counties with too much pollution face restrictions on business activities until ozone levels are reduced. Any emitter that wants to exceed those levels must find an offsetting source. 
"We know that this regulation could have been worse, but it still feels like a punch in the gut," said NAM's Tom Riordan. "Now manufacturers across this country, especially smaller companies, will be forced to choose between navigating this rule and hiring new workers, between complying with Washington's mandates and giving raises to their employees." Tougher ozone rules stir supporters, critics 
Environmental groups and health advocates said limits should have been lowered further. 
"When you have ridden in an ambulance with a child suffering through an asthma attack, the numbers take on a different meaning," Jessica Ulery, a mother and grandmother from Royal Center, said in a release put out by the Sierra Club. "I have witnessed this family having to plan trips within our state around air quality. We have a moral obligation to protect our children and all vulnerable to the hazardous effects of smog pollution." 
Ozone has been linked to premature deaths from respiratory and cardiovascular problems and can cause or aggravate asthma and other lung diseases. 
Ground-level ozone forms when sunlight interacts with pollutants from tailpipes, power plants, factories and other sources. 
The EPA is required by the Clean Air Act to review ozone standards every five years. It also must set rules based on health standards, not compliance costs. 
The agency's independent scientific advisory panel had recommended the level be set within a range of 60 to 70 parts per billion. 
The Obama administration chose 70 parts per billion, a tightening of the 75 parts-per-billion rule set in 2008. 
McCarthy said 72 parts per billion is the lowest exposure that causes problems for healthy adults, and the law requires a margin of safety, including for at-risk groups. EPA's new power plant rules tougher on Indiana 
Fourteen Indiana counties had ozone levels above 70 parts per billion in 2011 through 2013, the most recent three-year average figures available. Marion County's level was 74 parts per billion and is projected to fall to 60 parts per billion by 2025. 
McCarthy said the EPA most likely would apply the new rules in 2017, based on three-year average figures from 2014 through 2016. The length of time counties will have to comply will depend on "where you are now and how healthy your air is." The years that counties could be designated as not meeting the standards likely will range from 2020 to 2037, she said. 
"While the days are gone when cities like Los Angeles were so smoggy people had trouble seeing across the street, science tells us that ozone is still making people sick and we still have a lot of work to do," she said. 
Gov. Mike Pence had urged the EPA not to tighten the pollution limit. Pence encourages states to fight greenhouse gas rules 
Manufacturers and other business groups also lobbied heavily against the change. Indiana was among the states targeted in NAM's multimillion-dollar ad campaign. 
Sen. Dan Coats, R-Ind., is backing legislation that would block new standards until most areas meet current limits. 
"States and counties across the nation are still working to meet the current standard, and the administration should focus on helping states and communities achieve these existing standards before changing the rules," Coats said in a statement. 
Although opponents hope the GOP-controlled Congress can stop the new rules, Republicans don't have enough seats to override a veto by President Barack Obama. 
Email Maureen Groppe at mgroppe@gannett.com. Follow her on Twitter: @mgroppe.
